Different Crime.Crime Name: Failure to disclose dependants in immigration application
legal_basis: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Different Crime.Crime Name: Failure to declare dependent under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
humanitarian_and_compassionate_factors: errors in assessing education and establishment factors
immigration_status: not declared as a dependent in 1995
decision_outcome: matter remitted for reconsideration by a different officer
evidence_assessment: misapprehension of evidence regarding education and establishment

decision_reasoning: failed to provide adequate reasons regarding establishment
application_details: applicant's father neglected to declare him
applied for an inland exemption on H&C grounds
result_of_case: remanded for reconsideration by a different officer
procedure_followed: Judicial review was sought and granted

judicial_review_process: Federal Court analyzed legal tests and evidence assessment
administrative_error: errors in reasoning and evidence consideration
burden_of_proof: officer must consider all factors globally

misrepresentation_or_fraud: spouse did not disclose marriage prior to gaining permanent residency

applicable_regulations: Section 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
cause_of_action: Applicant's wife did not disclose her marriage when applying for permanent residency

Different Crime.Crime Name: Misrepresentation of material facts in immigration application

best_interests_of_children: close relationship with his sister and her husband
decision_reasoning: officer erred by not considering Johnathan's interests fully
application_details: focus on Johnathan's linguistic skills and education
applicant's mother failed to declare him initially

legal_basis: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act section 25
evidence_assessment: relied solely on minor discrepancies in interviews
humanitarian_and_compassionate_factors: request for exemption from visa requirements based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds

evidence_provided: documentary evidence supporting the marriage's genuineness

Different Crime.Crime Name: Failure to disclose family members on immigration application
legal_basis: s. 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
decision_outcome: Court granted judicial review, remitting the matter for re-determination by a different officer
misrepresentation_or_fraud: Sponsor failed to disclose family members in his initial immigration application

residency_requirement: three years of residence in Canada within the four years preceding their application
application_details: appellant accumulated only 357 days of residence instead of the required 1,095 days
studying abroad does not fulfill the residency requirement
result_of_case: required to fulfill the residency requirement before reapplying
procedure_followed: court analyzed the statutory language and purpose of the residency requirement

Different Crime.Crime Name: Submitting Counterfeit Documents under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
evidence_assessment: could have induced an error if undiscovered

risk_characterization: risked incorrect administration of the Act

legal_basis: sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
credibility_findings: prolonged stay in Burundi despite claimed threats
risk_of_persecution: land dispute with potential ethnic tensions

humanitarian_and_compassionate_considera: rejection based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds

decision_outcome: case remanded for reassessment by a new panel

refugee_status_nexus: denied based on credibility issues and perceived lack of subjective fear
evidence_consideration: delay in departure does not automatically indicate lack of subjective fear
delay in fleeing was due to hope for improvement, not lack of fear
legal_basis: Judicial review application under IRPA section 72 challenging RPD's decision

risk_assessment: subjective fear must consider cumulative incidents
discrepancies_identified: delay in departure improperly used to infer lack of subjective fear

reasonableness_standard: The Board's decision must be reasonable and supported by evidence, considering mixed questions of fact and law.
risk_of_persecution: persecution risk in China due to Tibetan ethnicity
evidence_assessment: ignoring obstacles like discretionary approval from Indian officials and the Central Tibetan Authority's reluctance
decision_outcome: The application for judicial review was allowed, and the matter was returned to another panel for reconsideration.
review_standard: Judicial review analyzed whether the Board reasonably concluded Mr. Wanchuk could live safely in India.

risk_of_persecution: indirect persecution linked to her son's political activities
procedural_fairness: RPD reviewed the claim, rejected it
decision_outcome: does not qualify as a refugee or person in need of protection
specific_group_membership: linked to her son's political activities
burden_of_proof: requiring proof of past persecution or future risk
evidence_assessment: no personal danger to her, noting she wasn't politically active and faced no direct threats

cause_incident: Dispute over overlapping land claims between SKDB, NBDB, and ADKFN
rule_regulation: The Crown has a duty to consult Aboriginal groups when contemplating actions that might adversely affect their rights
decision_standard: Scope of consultation depends on the strength of the claim and potential impact
application_details: Canada delayed consultations with SKDB and NBDB until after an agreement in principle with ADKFN
court_ruling: Court declared Canada breached its duty to consult
result_of_case: Ordered immediate substantive consultations with SKDB and NBDB
procedure_followed: Judicial review application filed by SKDB and NBDB

decision_reasoning: Court upheld Referee's decision as reasonable and procedurally fair
result_of_case: Application for judicial review dismissed without costs
cause_of_action: Dispute over unpaid commissions and performance bonus after termination
procedure_followed: Inspector investigated, Referee reviewed appeal, Court conducted judicial review
natural_justice_principles: no violation of natural justice principles

Different Crime.Crime Name: Negligence in Search and Rescue Duties
cause_of_action: negligence in search and rescue duties
procedure_followed: Defendants moved to strike or stay the action
decision_made: motion to strike the in personam action is dismissed
result_of_case: in personam action continues in Federal Court

reasonableness_of_decision: reasonable based on evidence showing opportunities for escape and active participation
credibility_findings: rejected claim of captivity and inability to escape

complicity_in_crimes: Participated in NPFL raids over four years
judicial_review_process: Analyzed whether the Board ignored evidence and misapplied duress principles

legal_basis: Correctional officials owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable steps to protect them from foreseeable harm. Liability arises if negligence causes damage.
decision_reasoning: Officials lacked actual knowledge of incompatibilities and followed standard procedures. Some omissions occurred but did not directly cause harm.
cause_of_action: Plaintiff was stabbed and later placed in protective custody due to perceived risks from other inmates.
procedure_followed: Trial examined actions of correctional officials at Matsqui, Mission, and Kent Institutions regarding transfers and safety measures.
result_of_case: Action dismissed with costs; no negligence established.

legal_basis: Correctional officials owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable steps to protect them from foreseeable harm.
risk_assessment: Lacked actual knowledge of incompatibility before the stabbing.
One official failed to communicate potential risks but no direct injury resulted.
decision_outcome: No breach of duty occurred as officials acted reasonably given available information.
Action dismissed; no liability found against the Crown.

remedy_requested: full review of humanitarian and compassionate claims

standard_of_review: judicial review under s 18 of the Federal Courts Act
decision_reasoning: did not involve a new exercise of discretion
application_details: Judicial review application filed by Mr. Snook
cause_of_action: Dispute over the implementation of the CDS's decision
procedure_followed: Judicial review application challenging the JAG's letter and CAF's implementation actions
decision_made: The letter is not a 'decision' amenable to judicial review

risk_assessment: fear of persecution from abusive ex-partner
refugee_status_nexus: claimant must prove state cannot protect

legal_basis: section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

decision_reasoning: not citizens nor involved in Canadian proceedings
application_details: non-Canadians interviewed by Canadian officials at Guantanamo Bay
procedure_followed: Judicial review of refusal to disclose records
analysis of Charter applicability and section 7 rights
result_of_case: no costs awarded due to uncertain legal state

relevant_rule: patent presumed valid unless proven otherwise
application_details: Apotex's product uses drospirenone dissolved in a matrix, not micronized as claimed in the '426 patent
decision_reasoning: Bayer failed to prove that this form infringes the claims at issue
cause_of_action: prohibition of Apotex obtaining approval for its generic version of YAZ until the '426 patent expired
procedure_steps: eligibility of the patent for listing under NOC Regulations

credibility_findings: no credible evidence of forced marriages in Liberia for men

decision_outcome: remanded to the Minister for redetermination

procedural_fairness: no breach of procedural fairness as evidence was not central
risk_assessment: Strachn claimed risk from Jamaican gangs, rejected due to insufficient credible evidence
evidence_assessment: applicant alleged risks from Jamaican gangs but provided insufficient new evidence to rebut prior findings
officer noted inconsistencies but found them non-central
standard_of_review: judicial review analyzed H&C and PRRA decisions under reasonableness standard
decision_outcome: H&C decision overturned, PRRA decision upheld

procedural_fairness: failed to mention previous H&C approval
evidence_consideration: officer failed to consider all evidence

procedural_fairness: Judicial review process analyzed under immigration laws and procedural rules
decision_outcome: Court allowed judicial review of both February 8 and April 20 decisions
standard_of_review: judicial review must be sought within 30 days of a decision
regulatory_compliance: visa officer can review prior decisions unless functus officio

reasoning_given: investigator's failure to meet procedural fairness standards
human_rights_concerns: alleged harassment and discrimination based on sex, race, and ethnicity

evidence_presented: participated in a CUSO program in Nigeria
maintained bank accounts, a driver's license, and family ties in Canada
procedure_followed: re-evaluating evidence under a flexible interpretation of residency rules

conclusion_outcome: decision is set aside for reconsideration
procedure_followed: based on documentary evidence without interview

state_protection_analysis: inadequate state protection for domestic violence victims in St. Lucia
reasonableness_of_decision: RPD's decision was unreasonable due to ignoring negative evidence
refugee_status_nexus: claim based on domestic violence and lack of state protection

procedural_fairness: Judicial review assessed whether the PRRA officer's decision was reasonable based on new evidence presented post-rejection.
evidence_provided: most evidence was deemed repetitive or insufficiently personalized to prove individual risk beyond general conditions in Bangladesh
reasonableness_standard: The PRRA officer's decision was reasonable as the new evidence did not substantiate a significant change in circumstances or personal risk
risk_characterization: Is the applicant at risk of extortion and persecution if returned to Bangladesh
nexus_to_convention_grounds: warranting protection under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

legal_basis: Section 113 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
standard_of_proof: sufficient new evidence to warrant protection

Different Crime.Crime Name: Impunity for Extrajudicial Killings (Border document misrepresentation)
legal_basis: section 113 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
new_evidence_impact: Three letters offered no materially new evidence
judicial_review_process: Court dismissed the judicial review, upholding the PRRA officer's decision
persecution_grounds: Applicant feared persecution in Bangladesh due to a documentary exposing RAB officers' wrongdoings

risk_assessment: personal risk of assault or cruel treatment
specific_threats_or_incidents: threatened and assaulted by a gang over months
procedural_fairness: judicial review application analyzed under the standard of patent unreasonableness

application_details: applicant was threatened multiple times by a gang over several months
conclusion_outcome: judicial review application is allowed, and the case is referred back for redetermination
cause_of_action: applicant claimed he faced personal threats from a gang in El Salvador and sought refugee status in Canada
procedure_followed: judicial review of the RPD's decision, applying the standard of patent unreasonableness
result_of_case: RPD's decision was overturned, and the case sent for reconsideration
